stem: The nurse is caring for a patient with suspected sepsis. Based on the patient's current condition and available data, determine which interventions are indicated and which are contraindicated. Select appropriate cells in each row.

itemContext.sbar: S: John Smith, 78-year-old male, admitted at 07:00 with suspected pneumonia, history of COPD and Diabetes Mellitus. B: Since 10:00, noted increased confusion and decreased urine output. Vitals: Temp 38.9°C, HR 110 bpm, RR 28 breaths/min, BP 88/50 mmHg, SpO2 91% on 2L nasal cannula. Labs pending. A: Concern for sepsis secondary to pneumonia. Blood cultures ordered, awaiting results. Lactate 3.5 mmol/L. Alert and oriented to person/place. Broad-spectrum antibiotics (Vancomycin & Cefepime) initiated at 11:00. R: Requires close monitoring, especially BP and urine output. Possible fluid bolus for hypotension. Continue antibiotics. Monitor urine output hourly, report deterioration immediately. Last bowel movement three days ago. Foley catheter inserted at 11:30, yielding 30mL amber urine. Current time: 12:00.

tabs.title: Labs
tabs.content: WBC: 18,000/mm3; Lactate: 3.5 mmol/L; Creatinine: 2.1 mg/dL; BUN: 35 mg/dL; Blood Cultures: Pending; Urine Cultures: Pending; Procalcitonin: 2.8 ng/mL

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content: Vancomycin 1.5g IV q12h (Started 11:00); Cefepime 2g IV q8h (Started 11:00); Acetaminophen 650mg PO PRN fever >38.5°C; Docusate 100mg PO daily; Normal Saline 0.9% IV at 100mL/hr

rationale.correct: Administering a fluid bolus is indicated to address the patient's hypotension, a key sign of sepsis-induced hypoperfusion. Monitoring urine output hourly is crucial for assessing renal function and response to fluid resuscitation. Continuing antibiotics is essential to combat the suspected infection. Initiating vasopressors is indicated if hypotension persists despite adequate fluid resuscitation; the current BP of 88/50 suggests this may be necessary soon. clinicalPearl: Early intervention in sepsis is critical.
rationale.incorrect: Administering an anti-diarrheal is contraindicated because the patient is constipated, not experiencing diarrhea. Restricting fluids is contraindicated in sepsis as the patient is hypotensive and requires fluid resuscitation to improve tissue perfusion. Discontinuing antibiotics is contraindicated as the patient has a suspected infection and the antibiotics are crucial for treatment. Administering a potassium supplement is not indicated based on the provided information; there is no indication of hypokalemia. questionTrap: Overlooking the complete clinical picture of sepsis (hypotension, tachycardia, altered mental status) by focusing solely on one aspect (e.g., fever) can lead to incorrect decisions.
clinicalPearls: Early recognition and treatment of sepsis are crucial to improving patient outcomes.
The Surviving Sepsis Campaign guidelines provide evidence-based recommendations for managing sepsis.
Monitor for signs of multi-drug resistance, especially in patients with recent antibiotic use or hospitalizations.

questionTrap.trap: The question trap lies in focusing solely on one aspect of the patient's presentation (e.g., fever) without considering the overall clinical picture of sepsis, which includes hypotension, tachycardia, and altered mental status.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Carefully evaluate all available data (vitals, labs, SBAR) to identify the key signs and symptoms of sepsis and determine the appropriate interventions based on the complete clinical picture.

mnemonic.title: SEPSIS
mnemonic.expansion: Seek source, Early antibiotics, Prevent hypotension, Suppress inflammation, Individualize treatment, Support organ function.

rows: Initiate vasopressors if hypotension persists after fluid resuscitation.
